posts.name: Owen Tharp
posts.cooked:
Our robot uses a Rev color sensor V3 for proximity detection, which we had available in the lab. It faces upward searching for coral, and when proximity exceeds 120, a boolean flip occurs. Initially, everything worked fine, but during a match at SMR, the elevator and arm began to shake erratically. Log files didn’t show immediate issues, but after several matches, the shaking persisted. We hypothesized it was an unusual issue unlikely to recur, but it returned during a final practice match.

The log showed a sudden jump in code cycle times from approximately 9 ms to over 500 ms. No gradual increase or variable changes were observed. The jump occurred instantaneously, followed by autolog messages and remaining in periodic tasks. We considered potential causes, such as an I2C port issue, but the FTCs dismissed it as more likely a crash rather than lag. Without further clues, we removed some simulation code to rule out real-world operation issues and continued testing.

During analysis, screenshots and videos from two matches showed similar symptoms. In both cases, the robot exhibited the erratic behavior. A closer examination revealed an issue in the intake.java file, specifically related to the rev color sensor configuration. Despite simplifying the intake file, the problem remained elusive, indicating minimal consistency in triggering factors.

The latest match, match 112, replicated the issue, and detailed logs identified the root cause in intake.java. Attempts to modify the code suggested potential fixes, though the inconsistency in the problem made resolution challenging.

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked: The intake subsystem appears to function correctly. I don’t see any immediate issues related to it if the problem originates elsewhere. However, I am uncertain about the accuracy of your LoggedTracer in capturing all relevant metrics. Understanding the command scheduler documentation is crucial. Each periodic method is executed sequentially. If a subsystem or command takes longer than usual to execute, the LoggedTracer might attribute extended periods to subsequent subsystems, creating the illusion of delayed performance in another area. A detailed explanation reveals that the system's timing can be misleading due to how LoggedTracer records timestamps. If a subsystem's periodic method is slow, the recorded timestamp may reflect elapsed time rather than recent activity, causing incorrect attribution of delays. Additionally, inconsistent usage of LoggedTracer across subsystems can lead to similar inaccuracies. Both factors could explain why the intake subsystem is incorrectly identified as experiencing delays. While I don't believe the intake itself is problematic, further investigation is recommended. A potential solution involves replacing the LoggedTracer with subsystem-specific loggers to more accurately measure individual periodic method durations.

link_counts.title: The Command Scheduler — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Several teams over the last few years have reported issues with the Rio I2C / Rev color sensor causing very long delays (in the 100s of ms range), not just system lockups. Moving the I2C sensor to an alternative such as a Pi Pico using the GitHub - ThadHouse/picocolorsensor Rev V3 Library for Raspberry Pi Pico is a good way to work around this issue.

link_counts.title: GitHub - ThadHouse/picocolorsensor: Rev V3 Library for Raspberry Pi Pico

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: Yep, we saw this in 2022 with the red vs. blue ball identification.

posts.name: Steven Carmain
posts.cooked: We moved the I2C read to a separate thread in 2022. Does that effectively mitigate the problem also as the I2C thread could lag but your robot code can run on the other core with no issues?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: It would prevent the loop overrun (if you've properly mutex’ed), but your data could potentially become stale over time.
